title: Akiko Sugimoto
text:
Akiko Sugimoto (May 28, 1953 December 4, 2015) was a Japanese novelist. She is best known for writing historical fiction about famous people who lived during the <a href="Edo%20period">Edo period</a>.
Early life and education.
Sugimoto was born on May 28, 1953 in the city of Yameshi in <a href="Fukuoka%20Prefecture">Fukuoka prefecture</a>. When she was a year old her legs were paralyzed by <a href="polio">polio</a>. Her father worked at a university and knew a lot about Japanese literature and history. As a child, Sugimoto read avidly from her father's library, especially his collection of <a href="gesaku">gesaku</a>. She was also fascinated with <a href="kabuki">kabuki</a>. After graduating from high school she decided that she wanted to live independently from her parents, and moved to Okayama prefecture where she attended <a href="Notre%20Dame%20Seishin%20University">Notre Dame Seishin University</a>. She later earned a master's degree from <a href="Kinjo%20Gakuin%20University">Kinjo Gakuin University</a> in 1978. Her master's thesis was about <a href="Terakado%20Seiken">Terakado Seiken</a>.
Career.
Sugimoto revisited Terakado as a subject in her debut story, . Her first novel, was published in 1983. It is about <a href="Tsutaya%20J%C5%ABzabur%C5%8D">Tsutaya Jusaburo</a>, the publisher for the painter <a href="Sharaku">Sharaku</a>. Her 1988 novel won the 100th <a href="Naoki%20Prize">Naoki Prize</a> alongside <a href="Shizuko%20T%C5%8Dd%C5%8D">Shizuko Tōdō</a>. In 1990 she wrote , which was about one of the rakugoka who used the artist name . While she mostly wrote about the Edo period, she sometimes also wrote about the Meiji period, such as in her 1995 , which was published in the <a href="The%20Asahi%20Shimbun">Asahi Shinbun</a> over the course of a year.
In 2002 her novel won the . The book became a series, which ended in 2008. It was her first series and the only one she completed.
Sugimoto died of <a href="breast%20cancer">breast cancer</a> on December 4, 2015.
